Articles: {"abstract": "Samsung Electronics will report its fourth-quarter earnings estimates, the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma will begin and the European Central Bank will review its monetary policy.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/06/business/economy/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-jan-6.html", "snippet": "Samsung Electronics will report its fourth-quarter earnings estimates, the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma will begin and the European Central Bank will review its monetary policy.", "lead_paragraph": "SAMSUNG EARNINGS 2014 will be a tough year for Samsung Electronics, the largest cellphone and television maker in the world. Its stock recently took a beating amid concerns of slowing profit growth from smartphone sales, and the company is under pressure to continue releasing innovative new products to compete with Apple and a crop of handset makers in China. On Tuesday, when the South Korean giant is expected to report earnings estimates for the fourth quarter, investors will keep a close eye on the company\u2019s sales of cellphones, televisions and other items during the holiday shopping season, the most lucrative time of year for electronics manufacturers. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 6", "kicker": "Looking Ahead", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Samsung Electronics Co", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Insider Trading", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Martoma, Mathew", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "European Central Bank", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-01-06T01:12:58+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Economy", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Schedule", "_id": "nyt://article/e08aec1f-9e20-572c-abad-c72dbfa9dd1a", "word_count": 234, "uri": "nyt://article/e08aec1f-9e20-572c-abad-c72dbfa9dd1a"}

{"abstract": "Suntory of Japan is buying Jim Beam for $13.6 billion. | Bank of America tells its junior bankers to take a day off. | Sides trade harsh words at trial of former SAC trader. | Bank regulators back down on leverage ratio.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/01/13/morning-agenda-suntorys-deal-for-jim-beam/", "snippet": "Suntory of Japan is buying Jim Beam for $13.6 billion. | Bank of America tells its junior bankers to take a day off. | Sides trade harsh words at trial of former SAC trader. | Bank regulators back down on leverage ratio.", "lead_paragraph": "Suntory, known for producing Japan\u2019s first whiskey, has agreed to acquire the maker of Jim Beam and Maker\u2019s Mark bourbons, among other spirits, for $13.6 billion, DealBook reports. Including the assumption of debt, the deal is valued at $16 billion. Suntory is offering Jim Beam shareholders $83.50 a share in cash, 25 percent above the company\u2019s closing price on Friday.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Suntory\u2019s Deal for Jim Beam", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-01-13T13:47:46+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a39eba5b-5994-51c6-9328-4f67edc468e9", "word_count": 2089, "uri": "nyt://article/a39eba5b-5994-51c6-9328-4f67edc468e9"}

Gox, the most prominent Bitcoin exchange, late Monday night naturally stirred outrage and panic. After all, a document circulating widely in the Bitcoin world said the company had lost 744,000 Bitcoins \u2014 about 6 percent of Bitcoins in circulation \u2014 worth more than $300 million at current exchange rates. But Bitcoin\u2019s latest troubles did little to shake the confidence of many, and indeed, the virtual currency\u2019s stumble may provide just the spark it needs to become a more mature part of the financial system, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A Silver Lining in Bitcoin\u2019s Stumble", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-02-26T12:31:04+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/3d689182-ed93-5aa3-a168-bbc0aa485e51", "word_count": 2918, "uri": "nyt://article/3d689182-ed93-5aa3-a168-bbc0aa485e51"}

{"abstract": "Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into fraud involving Citigroup\u2019s Mexican unit. | Blythe Masters, the head of JPMorgan Chase\u2019s commodities unit, is leaving the bank. | China\u2019s answer to Wall Street. | Rendering a strong case against Bank of America weak.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/04/03/morning-agenda-shadows-over-citigroup/", "snippet": "Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into fraud involving Citigroup\u2019s Mexican unit. | Blythe Masters, the head of JPMorgan Chase\u2019s commodities unit, is leaving the bank. | China\u2019s answer to Wall Street. | Rendering a strong cas...", "lead_paragraph": "Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into a recent $400 million fraud involving Citigroup\u2019s Mexican unit, according to people briefed on the matter, one of a handful of government inquiries looming over the giant bank, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write in DealBook. The investigation, overseen by the F.B.I. and prosecutors from the United States attorney\u2019s office in Manhattan, is focusing in part on whether holes in the bank\u2019s internal controls contributed to the fraud in Mexico.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Shadows Over Citigroup", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-04-03T11:37:17+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/3232a5ec-9c89-5206-bcd8-ccb40630bdec", "word_count": 2429, "uri": "nyt://article/3232a5ec-9c89-5206-bcd8-ccb40630bdec"}

{"abstract": "Bank of America\u2019s mortgage settlement is said to be deadlocked. | The manager of Harvard\u2019s endowment plans to step down. | A.I.G. has named its next chief executive. | The banking industry is trying to adapt to stricter regulations and low market volatility.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/06/11/morning-agenda-an-impasse-in-bank-of-america-settlement/", "snippet": "Bank of America\u2019s mortgage settlement is said to be deadlocked. | The manager of Harvard\u2019s endowment plans to step down. | A.I.G. has named its next chief executive. | The banking industry is trying to adapt to stricter regulations and low market ...", "lead_paragraph": " BANK OF AMERICA SETTLEMENT DEADLOCKED \u00a0|\u00a0 Bank of America and the Justice Department have reached an impasse in negotiations over a multibillion-dollar settlement, raising the stakes in an investigation into the bank\u2019s role at the center of the mortgage crisis, DealBook\u2019s Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write. The talks stalled on Monday after the bank\u2019s latest offer, at more than $12 billion, was said to be far short of prosecutors\u2019 demands. The Justice Department has sought a settlement worth roughly $17 billion, which would be the largest payout by any bank to date.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: An Impasse in Bank of America Settlement", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-06-11T14:46:07+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f767343f-c68f-5b19-b412-d2357faa1f1a", "word_count": 1786, "uri": "nyt://article/f767343f-c68f-5b19-b412-d2357faa1f1a"}

{"abstract": "Bank of America offered the U.S. the biggest settlement in history. | T-Mobile taunted Sprint after a takeover plan fell apart. | Why Walgreen shied away from an inversion in its deal for Alliance Boots. | Time Warner was silent on 21st Century Fox\u2019s takeover attempt during its earnings call on Wednesday.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/07/morning-agenda-bank-of-americas-big-mortgage-settlement/", "snippet": "Bank of America offered the U.S. the biggest settlement in history. | T-Mobile taunted Sprint after a takeover plan fell apart. | Why Walgreen shied away from an inversion in its deal for Alliance Boots. | Time Warner was silent on 21st Century Fo...", "lead_paragraph": "BANK OF AMERICA NEARS DEAL WITH JUSTICE DEPT. | After months of talks, Bank of America suddenly caved in to the government, agreeing to the largest single federal settlement in the history of corporate America, DealBook\u2019s Ben Protess and Michael Corkery write. {"abstract": "If it provides hard cash for demolishing abandoned homes, an impending settlement by Bank of America could help many forgotten victims of the mortgage crisis.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/17/business/in-a-bank-settlement-dont-forget-the-bulldozers.html", "snippet": "If it provides hard cash for demolishing abandoned homes, an impending settlement by Bank of America could help many forgotten victims of the mortgage crisis.", "lead_paragraph": "A win-win. That\u2019s how people on both sides of the negotiating table will undoubtedly characterize the long-awaited, $16 billion-plus mortgage settlement that Bank of America is expected to reach with the Justice Department this week. For federal and state governments, the deal will mean billions in cash and borrower assistance. For the bank, the agreement will help it get past its mortgage woes, many emanating from its 2008 purchase of Countrywide Financial, a truly toxic lender. {"abstract": "Standard Chartered to will pay a $300 million fine for backsliding. | A default swaps association has postponed a payout auction on Argentine bonds. | Grappling with the cost of corporate gadflies. | Bank of America has a sole chief operating officer.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/20/morning-agenda-standard-chartereds-backsliding-woes/", "snippet": "Standard Chartered to will pay a $300 million fine for backsliding. | A default swaps association has postponed a payout auction on Argentine bonds. | Grappling with the cost of corporate gadflies. | Bank of America has a sole chief operating offi...", "lead_paragraph": "In a settlement announced on Tuesday by New York State\u2019s financial regulator, the British bank Standard Chartered will pay a $300 million fine and suspend its dollar-clearing activities because of its failure to weed out transactions prone to money-laundering, Ben Protess and Chad Bray write in DealBook. The deal comes two years after the bank paid a combined $667 million to state and federal authorities over similar accusations. Those settlements resolved accusations that Standard Chartered, in part through its New York branch, processed transactions for Iran and other countries blacklisted by the United States.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Standard Chartered\u2019s Backsliding Woes", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-08-20T11:36:41+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/0492773d-6ba9-56b1-a0eb-448974f37205", "word_count": 1949, "uri": "nyt://article/0492773d-6ba9-56b1-a0eb-448974f37205"}

{"abstract": "The Bank of America settlement may close a chapter of the financial crisis, but the Justice Department can still pursue civil cases against former Countrywide executives, writes Peter J. Henning in the White Collar Watch column.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/22/blurred-lines-in-big-bank-mortgage-settlements/", "snippet": "The Bank of America settlement may close a chapter of the financial crisis, but the Justice Department can still pursue civil cases against former Countrywide executives, writes Peter J. Henning in the White Collar Watch column.", "lead_paragraph": "The latest settlement with a big bank, this time Bank of America\u2019s $16.65 billion resolution over shoddy mortgage and related mortgage-backed securities that lost much of their value, has all the accoutrements we have come to expect: a claim of historic significance supported by a statement of facts referencing a few embarrassing e-mails to establish the requisite venality for a large penalty. A prominent feature is a news conference where Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. hails the resolution as yet another blow against the reckless (or worse) banking practices that led to the financial crisis.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, {"abstract": "Bank of America takes a $400 million legal charge. | Details emerge on low-down-payment mortgage plan. | More twists in battle for Allergan.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/11/07/morning-agenda-bank-of-americas-legal-hit/", "snippet": "Bank of America takes a $400 million legal charge. | Details emerge on low-down-payment mortgage plan. | More twists in battle for Allergan.", "lead_paragraph": "BANK OF AMERICA RAISES LEGAL COSTS | Bank of America said in a news release on Thursday that it was nearing a deal with federal regulators to settle an investigation into the bank\u2019s suspected manipulation of the currency market, saying it had increased its legal costs to deal with the inquiry, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. The increased legal bill resulted in a $400 million charge that cut into the earnings that Bank of America reported for the third quarter a few weeks ago. The charge resulted in the bank\u2019s reporting a loss of $232 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Bank of America\u2019s Legal Hit", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-11-07T12:29:12+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/d5cd449d-90cd-5680-a8e4-dea6b3fee35f", "word_count": 2619, "uri": "nyt://article/d5cd449d-90cd-5680-a8e4-dea6b3fee35f"}

{"abstract": "Goldman names John E. Waldron co-head of its investment bank. | Regulators deem MetLife \u201ctoo big to fail.\u201d | Another big whistle-blower reward in Bank of America case. | London tenants win battle over U.S. equity firm.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/morning-agenda-goldman-promotes-star-deal-maker/", "snippet": "Goldman names John E. Waldron co-head of its investment bank. | Regulators deem MetLife \u201ctoo big to fail.\u201d | Another big whistle-blower reward in Bank of America case. | London tenants win battle over U.S. equity firm.", "lead_paragraph": "GOLDMAN PROMOTES STAR DEAL MAKER | Goldman Sachs has promoted John E. Waldron, one of the bank\u2019s star deal makers, to become a co-head of its investment bank, succeeding John S. Weinberg, a scion of one of the firm\u2019s most famous families, DealBook\u2019s Michael J. de la Merced reports. The move will put Mr. Waldron in charge, along with Richard Gnodde and David Solomon, of running the firm\u2019s prominent corporate advisory practice. The announcement on Thursday is the latest change in the leadership of Goldman\u2019s powerful investment bank.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Goldman Promotes Star Deal Maker", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-12-19T18:56:02+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f021f02e-6f33-5e33-9a28-60bc5275682a", "word_count": 2181, "uri": "nyt://article/f021f02e-6f33-5e33-9a28-60bc5275682a"}

{"abstract": "A report suggests that a program intended to help as many as four million troubled borrowers has allowed big banks to run roughshod over them again and again.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/02/business/pulling-down-underwater-borrowers.html", "snippet": "A report suggests that a program intended to help as many as four million troubled borrowers has allowed big banks to run roughshod over them again and again.", "lead_paragraph": "After Lucy Circe became disabled and could no longer work, she applied to Bank of America for a mortgage loan modification on her Vermont home. Over more than two years, starting in 2012, the bank repeatedly requested copies of documents that had already been provided, asked for proof that she was no longer married to a man she did not even know, and made other errors, like asking why Ms. Circe had indicated that she didn\u2019t want to keep her property when she had actually told the bank she did.", "print_section": "BU", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A Slack Lifeline for Drowning Homeowners", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Slack Lifeline for Drowning Homeowners", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Morgenson, Gretchen (Per)", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mortgages", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Treasury Department", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Banking and Financial Institutions", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Real Estate and Housing (Residential)", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Subprime Mortgage Crisis", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Foreclosures", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-07-31T11:00:04+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "SundayBusiness", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Gretchen Morgenson", "person": [{"firstname": "Gretchen", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Morgenson", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/97eb7279-bdd7-530e-a531-20a3a72ef924", "word_count": 1230, "uri": "nyt://article/97eb7279-bdd7-530e-a531-20a3a72ef924"}

{"abstract": "Cutting costs and eliminating huge legal bills have helped the bank, but its rivals are ahead on efficiency, among other areas.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/15/business/dealbook/bank-of-americas-hunt-for-growth.html", "snippet": "Cutting costs and eliminating huge legal bills have helped the bank, but its rivals are ahead on efficiency, among other areas.", "lead_paragraph": "Wells Fargo and JPMorgan have reported third-quarter results that highlight a $7 billion challenge for rival Bank of America. That\u2019s the extra annual profit the lender run by Brian Moynihan would need to earn for a 10 percent return on equity, generally the level at which big banks cover their cost of capital. Cutting spending to match Wells Fargo\u2019s efficient operation would not quite suffice, though. And JPMorgan proved on Tuesday that it can manage passable results even when revenue falls.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Bank of America\u2019s Hunt for Growth", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Bank of America Corporation", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "JPMorgan Chase & Company", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wells Fargo & Company", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Banking and Financial Institutions", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Moynihan, Brian T", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Dimon, James", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-10-15T01:55:57+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Antony Currie", "person": [{"firstname": "Antony", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Currie", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/3073b9ef-3f52-579d-82ce-c0def54c8a0c", "word_count": 399, "uri": "nyt://article/3073b9ef-3f52-579d-82ce-c0def54c8a0c"}

{"abstract": "A fourth-quarter fizzle for most large banks is followed by a steep drop in their market value in the first two weeks of the first quarter.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/16/business/dealbook/rocky-road-ahead-for-big-banks.html", "snippet": "A fourth-quarter fizzle for most large banks is followed by a steep drop in their market value in the first two weeks of the first quarter.", "lead_paragraph": "America\u2019s too-big-to-fail cabal is nursing $130 billion in damages. That\u2019s the amount of market value lost by the nation\u2019s top six banks in the last two weeks. The shares of all but Wells Fargo now trade below book value, suggesting stockholders are bracing for a year or more of pain. {"abstract": "The Justice Department forced banks to pay fines and penalties, but mystery surrounds the dearth of individual prosecutions for wrongdoing.", "web_url": mystery surrounds the dearth of individual prosecutions for wrongdoing.", "lead_paragraph": "One of the enduring mysteries of the 2008 financial crisis has been why the Justice Department made so few {"abstract": "The merger of the online stockbrokers still leaves such companies vulnerable to the competition of index investing and automation of advice.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/25/business/dealbook/td-ameritrades-deal-with-scottrade-is-a-temporary-fix.html", "snippet": "The merger of the online stockbrokers still leaves such companies vulnerable to the competition of index investing and automation of advice.", "lead_paragraph": "TD Ameritrade\u2019s $4 billion takeover of Scottrade merely delays the inevitable. Uniting the two American online stockbrokers stacks up financially, because of cost cuts, a tax break and a sale of a banking unit. Income and margins should rise, too.
